text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today I 
am making a new and improved video for laab

and laab is a very well-known North Eastern dish 
that's basically a salad made up of ground meat

and lots of fresh herbs it's really refreshing 
perfect for the summer now last time when I made

this years ago I used pork but today I'm going to 
show you how to make it with chicken because I've

got lots of people asking me hey I want to make 
laab chicken is there anything I need to know are

there any tricks so we're going to tackle all 
of that today let's get started so the heart

of laab is toasted rice powder or what we call cow 
kuat now cow is rice and kua means to sort of dry

toast something in a pan which is exactly what 
we're going to do so what I've got here is some

sticky rice okay raw uncooked sticky rice if you 
don't have sticky rice you can also just do this

with jasmine rice it'll work just as well but this 
is sort of traditional cuz sticky rice is the main

rice eaten in the Northeast and now what I'm going 
to do differently this time is instead of toasting

the rice naked I'm going to also throw in a kaffir 
lime leaf for this amount just oneness okay some

people also add pieces of lemon grass or galangal 
and allow it to toast with their rice now you want

to make sure you stir this all the time so the 
toasting is even okay and it's going to smoke a

lot don't worry it's normal and that looks good 
I'm gonna turn that off so you want the color to

be a nice deep brown not light golden brown here 
you want some color on it cuz that's how you're

gonna get a nice toasty nutty aroma add it to the 
salad I'm going to transfer this into my morton

pestle or you can use a coffee grinder if you 
want you can also see how crispy that leaf is

and you can actually grind that up together mmm 
so good if you're using a coffee grinder just

be careful you don't over grind it until it's a 
complete powder you still want a little bit of

a grittiness to it hmm the stuff is so magical 
all right there's that so just one little thing

before we get cooking is the chili flakes oh this 
is actually really important lab never uses fresh

chilies always dry like these and always roast 
it or toast it so these are not toasted you see

they're bright and red all I do is i roast this 
in the oven for a few minutes I'll include all

the specifics in the written recipe and I also 
throw in a lime leaf in the oven too when i

roast it just like the toast with rice powder 
and then I grind it up in a coffee grinder or

a mortar and pestle and it gives me really nice 
and a little bit smoky with that citrusy flavor

from the lime leaves that is good chili flakes 
all right time to grind our chicken now I don't

like to use commercially ground chicken for this 
you can but I find that they grind it too fine and

a lot of times it's way too lean so what I like to 
do is I've got 50% chicken thigh and I include the

fat because that's going to help sort of make it 
a little juicy because we're not adding any added

oil or anything at all and then the other half 
is chicken breasts and I think that's the nice

combination between fattiness and flavor and 
also the tenderness from the chicken breast so

I'm going to grind this using a cleaver which is 
something every household in Thailand does is very

common I grew up doing this ever since I was like 
a tiny tiny little kid and you just chop chop chop

so after you first go at it what I like to do 
is just flip it because a lot of times your

knife doesn't cut all the way through so if you 
flip it and cut it from the other side you sort

of you know you get it you get everything and 
then you can change the knife angle this way all

right so we're good to go so this is actually a 
one-pot dish we're gonna cook the chicken in here

and then this becomes essentially the salad bowl 
which is what I love just a couple tablespoons of

water here if you've got some unsalted chicken 
stock go ahead and use that it's better so the

technique we're using here is there's a special 
word for that in Thai and it's called good one

and one just means cooking something just in a 
pan with a little bit of oil or water like this

until it's done and the water is really just there 
to lubricate the pan I'm going to add the chicken

and one it and so what I'm going to do which is 
just my trick not everyone does is I'm going to

add just a little bit of fish sauce to the chicken 
right now and it's just to season it you know you

want to season it during and after so that the the 
flavor isn't just on the outside and the dressing

but also inside the meat keep stirring it you want 
to keep stirring it because you don't want it to

clump up together in a big chunk and also note 
that I am using a large ish pan if I crowd a small

pot it's going to trap a lot of water inside and 
then you end up with too much liquid if you use

a large pan the water can evaporate and you don't 
end up diluting your dressing okay that's it I'm

going to turn that off okay so now while this is 
still quite hot I'm going to add shallots thinly

sliced shallots and the heat of the chicken is 
going to help will the shallot and now I'm going

to go in with the seasoning so fish sauce and lime 
juice and that's it fish sauce and lime juice no

sugar whatsoever in-lap that's why you really 
need to have the toasted rice powder because

the toasted rice sort of the nuttiness of that 
will balance the sharp acidity and the saltiness

of the lime juice and the fish sauce so if you 
don't have that it's really a little bit abrasive

my toasted rice powder I will tell you one thing 
don't add this if you're not planning to serve

this right away because the toasted rice will sort 
of absorb all the liquid and just sort of swell up

but I'm gonna eat this right away so I can just 
go ahead and put it in and I like a lot you can

put as much or as little as you like but I like a 
lot mmm Oh as soon as you add that it smells like

love like instantly okay now some chili flakes 
this tends to be a spicy dish so don't be shy

salivating so now we're going to add the delicate 
herbs okay and the delicate herbs you want to add

later at the end because now it's not as hot so 
I'm going to go in with the green onions now this

is sawtooth coriander now sawtooth coriander is an 
iconic herb to add to lab it's sort of the flavor

sort of a cross between mint and cilantro it's 
really unique however it's not always easy to find

Vietnamese stores will have it so if you've got a 
Vietnamese grocery store nearby check them out if

you don't have it cilantro will work you can do 
both cilantro and / with coriander if you'd like

or one or the other a lot of times people will 
serve this on the side so you can sort of munch on

it ask your eating lab as well okay this is your 
first time making it make sure you give it a taste

hey I made this recipe so many times I know if 
isn't gonna be good alright so I've got some fresh

vegetables we always serve lab with lots of fresh 
veggies because this is really neat heavy right as

you can see and it's also really strong flavor so 
the vegetables help mellow it out in addition to

giving some freshness I know what you're thinking 
some of you are thinking but pile in where's the

mint the mint is like the most important thing 
here well I discover that it's better especially

if you're not going to eat it right away to put 
the mint on the outside because mint turns black

really quickly when it's exposed to heat so if 
you put it on the outside it'll look nicer and

then when you go to eat it you just mix it in as 
you eat it what's a classic garnish is we put a

couple of dried chilies on top and also what I'm 
going to do is I'm going to add some crunchiness

to it and that is crispy chicken skin so I have 
a video on how to make your own crispy chicken

skin I actually came up with with the method and 
basically I use the skin from the chicken that I

use for the lab so I'm just going to add a couple 
of pieces on top it's just extra crispy chicken

nests so you gotta have sticky rice with this okay 
I've got some ready to go in the bag which I'll

reheat and eat after we're done here but it goes 
really well with laughs now the way I like to eat

it is sort of as a lettuce wrap type thing and I 
actually really like having it with this Belgian

on d4 and I've however you like to call it it's 
like this nature's perfect spoon you don't have to

do anything to it it's just this perfect little 
cup mmm it is the most refreshing bright zingy

chicken salad you will ever have others everything 
is in such good balance to saltiness with a fish

sauce and tart lime juice and even though we 
didn't add any sugar just sort of the natural

sweetness of the chicken and the toastiness of 
the toasted rice powder just brings everything

to a really really yummy place and vegetables 
really really important in this oh this is so good

I can just keep going but anyway I got to get my 
sticky rice heated up so I can properly sit down

and devour this thing so the recipe SOA Fujian has 
Thai Kitchen comm when you make it send me a photo

on Facebook Twitter or Instagram and you haven't 
subscribed to the show do so right here so you

never miss an awesome recipe like this and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious time
